Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 20, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
The annals of Ancient Egyptian king 
Thutmose III described a marvelous foreign bird that “gives birth daily.” Zoroastrians viewed them as spirits whose cries told of the cosmic struggle between darkness and light. Romans brought them on
their military campaigns to foretell the success of future battles. And today, this bird still occupies
an important, though much less honorable position – on our dinner plates. The modern chicken is descended
primarily from the Red Junglefowl, and partially from three other 
closely related species, all native to India and Southeast Asia. The region’s bamboo plants produce massive amounts of fruit just once every few decades. Junglefowls’ ability to lay eggs daily may have evolved to take advantage 
of these rare feasts, increasing their population
when food was abundant. This was something humans could exploit on a consistent basis, and the birds’ weak flight capabilities and limited need for space made them easy to capture and contain. The earliest domesticated chickens, dating at least back to 7,000 years ago, weren’t bred for food, but for something considered
less savory today. The aggressiveness of breeding males, armed with natural leg spurs, made cockfighting a popular entertainment. By the second millennium BCE, chickens had spread from the 
Indus Valley to China and the Middle East to occupy
royal menageries and to be used in religious rituals. But it was in Egypt where the next chapter in
the bird’s history began. When a hen naturally incubates eggs, she will stop laying new ones and sit on a “clutch” of 6
or more eggs for 21 days. By the middle of the 1st millennium BCE, the Egyptians had learned to artificially incubate chicken eggs by placing them in baskets over hot ashes. That freed up hens to continue
laying daily, and what had been a royal delicacy or religious offering became a common meal. Around the same time as Egyptians
were incubating eggs, Phoenician merchants introduced
chickens to Europe, where they quickly became
an essential part of European livestock. However, for a long time, the chicken’s revered status 
continued to exist alongside its culinary one. The Ancient Greeks used fighting roosters as inspirational examples 
for young soldiers. The Romans consulted chickens as oracles. And as late as the 7th Century, the chicken was considered
a symbol for Christianity. Over the next few centuries, chickens accompanied humans
wherever they went, spreading throughout the world
through trade, conquest, and colonization. After the Opium Wars, Chinese breeds were brought to England and crossed with local chickens. This gave rise to a phenomenon called “Hen Fever” or “The Fancy”, with farmers all over Europe striving to breed new varieties with particular combinations of traits. This trend also caught the attention of a certain Charles Darwin,
who wondered if a similar selective breeding process
occurred in nature. Darwin would observe hundreds of chickens while finalizing his historic work introducing the theory of Evolution. But the chicken’s greatest
contribution to science was yet to come. In the early 20th century, a trio of British scientists conducted extensive crossbreeding
of chickens, building on Gregor Mendel’s studies of genetic inheritance. With their high genetic diversity, many distinct traits, and only 7 months between generations, chickens were the perfect subject. This work resulted in the famous
Punnett Square, used to show the genotypes
that would result from breeding a given pairing. Since then, numerous breeding initiatives
have made chickens bigger and meatier, and allowed them to lay 
more eggs than ever. Meanwhile, chicken production has shifted 
to an industrial, factory-like model, with birds raised in spaces 
with a footprint no larger than a sheet of paper. And while there’s been a shift
towards free-range farming due to animal rights 
and environmental concerns, most of the world’s more than
22 billion chickens today are factory farmed. From gladiators and gifts to the gods, to traveling companions 
and research subjects, chickens have played many roles
over the centuries. And though they may not have come 
before the proverbial egg, chickens’ fascinating history tells us 
a great deal about our own.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What part of the world is the native range of the Junglefowl?
Options: A. Southeast Asia, B. Egypt, C. Europe, D. China
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What bird is primarily descended from the Red Junglefowl and is native to India and Southeast Asia? Options: A. Peacock, B. Pheasant, C. Modern Chicken, D. Ostrich Correct Option: C
Question 2: Why did the ability of Junglefowls to lay eggs daily likely evolve? Options: A. To increase their population when predators were scarce, B. To take advantage of rare feasts from the region's bamboo plants, C. To adapt to the changing climate, D. To improve their flying capabilities Correct Option: B
Question 3: What was the primary purpose of domesticating chickens around 7,000 years ago? Options: A. For food, B. For cockfighting and entertainment, C. For use in religious rituals, D. For companionship Correct Option: B
Question 4: What innovation did the Egyptians develop to increase chicken egg production? Options: A. Artificial incubation of eggs using hot ashes, B. Selective breeding of chickens for desirable traits, C. Construction of large chicken coops, D. Development of chicken feed Correct Option: A
Question 5: What was the result of Phoenician merchants introducing chickens to Europe? Options: A. Chickens became a rare and exotic species, B. Chickens quickly became an essential part of European livestock, C. Chickens were only used for cockfighting, D. Chickens were only used for food Correct Option: B
Question 6: How did the Opium Wars influence the development of new chicken breeds in Europe? Options: A. Chinese breeds were brought to England and crossed with local chickens, giving rise to "Hen Fever", B. European breeds were introduced to China, leading to the development of new breeds, C. The Opium Wars had no impact on chicken breeding in Europe, D. The Opium Wars led to a decline in chicken breeding in Europe Correct Option: A
Question 7: What was Charles Darwin's contribution to the study of chickens? Options: A. He developed the Punnett Square to show genetic inheritance, B. He conducted extensive crossbreeding of chickens to study genetic diversity, C. He observed chickens and wondered if a similar selective breeding process occurred in nature, influencing his theory of Evolution, D. He discovered the Red Junglefowl as the primary ancestor of modern chickens Correct Option: C
Question 8: Why were chickens ideal subjects for studying genetic inheritance? Options: A. They have low genetic diversity and few distinct traits, B. They have a long generation time, making it easier to study genetic changes, C. They have high genetic diversity, many distinct traits, and a short generation time, D. They are easy to breed and have a large footprint Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is a major concern with the current industrial model of chicken production? Options: A. The high cost of production, B. The environmental impact and animal welfare concerns, C. The lack of genetic diversity in chicken breeds, D. The inability to meet global demand for chicken products Correct Option: B
Question 10: What can be inferred about human history and society from the study of chicken domestication and development? Options: A. Humans have always prioritized animal welfare and environmental concerns, B. Humans have a long history of exploiting animals for food, entertainment, and other purposes, C. Humans have only recently begun to domesticate animals, D. Humans have made little progress in understanding genetic inheritance and breeding Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 1. 

Although the question content is not an exact match, the options and overall intent of Question 1 are most similar to the ground truth MCQ. Both questions are related to the origin and native range of the Junglefowl or modern chicken. 

However, it's worth noting that a more direct match could be created by rephrasing Question 1 to focus specifically on the native range of the Junglefowl, rather than its descendant, the modern chicken.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 1

or more eggs for 21 days. By the middle of the 1st millennium BCE, the Egyptians had learned to artificially incubate chicken eggs by placing them in baskets over hot ashes. That freed up hens to continue
laying daily, and what had been a royal delicacy or religious offering became a common meal. Around the same time as Egyptians
were incubating eggs, Phoenician merchants introduced
chickens to Europe, where they quickly became
an essential part of European livestock. However, for a long time, the chicken’s revered status 
continued to exist alongside its culinary one. The Ancient Greeks used fighting roosters as inspirational examples 
for young soldiers. The Romans consulted chickens as oracles. And as late as the 7th Century, the chicken was considered
a symbol for Christianity. Over the next few centuries, chickens accompanied humans
wherever they went, spreading throughout the world
through trade, conquest, and colonization. After the Opium Wars, Chinese breeds were brought to England and crossed with local chickens. This gave rise to a phenomenon called “Hen Fever” or “The Fancy”, with farmers all over Europe striving to breed new varieties with particular combinations of traits. This trend also caught the attention of a certain Charles Darwin,
who wondered if a similar selective breeding process
occurred in nature. Darwin would observe hundreds of chickens while finalizing his historic work introducing the theory of Evolution. But the chicken’s greatest
contribution to science was yet to come. In the early 20th century, a trio of British scientists conducted extensive crossbreeding
of chickens, building on Gregor Mendel’s studies of genetic inheritance. With their high genetic diversity, many distinct traits, and only 7 months between generations, chickens were the perfect subject. This work resulted in the famous
Punnett Square, used to show the genotypes
that would result from breeding a given pairing. Since then, numerous breeding initiatives
have made chickens bigger and meatier, and allowed them to lay 
more eggs than ever. Meanwhile, chicken production has shifted 
to an industrial, factory-like model, with birds raised in spaces 
with a footprint no larger than a sheet of paper. And while there’s been a shift
towards free-range farming due to animal rights 
and environmental concerns, most of the world’s more than
22 billion chickens today are factory farmed. From gladiators and gifts to the gods, to traveling companions 
and research subjects, chickens have played many roles
over the centuries. And though they may not have come 
before the proverbial egg, chickens’ fascinating history tells us 
a great deal about our own.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Why were chickens influential in Charles Darwin’s development of the Theory of Evolution?
Options: A. Chickens make rapid changes between generations, B. Chickens are one of the oldest species, C. Chinese chickens adapted to their new European environment, D. If humans could breed so many different types of chicken, then so could nature
Correct Option: D

Question 1: What bird is primarily descended from the Red Junglefowl and is native to India and Southeast Asia? Options: A. Peacock, B. Pheasant, C. Modern Chicken, D. Ostrich Correct Option: C

To take advantage of rare feasts from the region's bamboo plants, C. To adapt to the changing climate, D. To improve their flying capabilities Correct Option: B
Question 3: What was the primary purpose of domesticating chickens around 7,000 years ago? Options: A. For food, B. For cockfighting and entertainment, C. For use in religious rituals, D. For companionship Correct Option: B
Question 4: What innovation did the Egyptians develop to increase chicken egg production? Options: A. Artificial incubation of eggs using hot ashes, B. Selective breeding of chickens for desirable traits, C. Construction of large chicken coops, D. Development of chicken feed Correct Option: A
Question 5: What was the result of Phoenician merchants introducing chickens to Europe? Options: A. Chickens became a rare and exotic species, B. Chickens quickly became an essential part of European livestock, C. Chickens were only used for cockfighting, D. Chickens were only used for food Correct Option: B
Question 6: How did the Opium Wars influence the development of new chicken breeds in Europe? Options: A. Chinese breeds were brought to England and crossed with local chickens, giving rise to "Hen Fever", B. European breeds were introduced to China, leading to the development of new breeds, C. The Opium Wars had no impact on chicken breeding in Europe, D. The Opium Wars led to a decline in chicken breeding in Europe Correct Option: A
Question 7: What was Charles Darwin's contribution to the study of chickens? Options: A. He developed the Punnett Square to show genetic inheritance, B. He conducted extensive crossbreeding of chickens to study genetic diversity, C. He observed chickens and wondered if a similar selective breeding process occurred in nature, influencing his theory of Evolution, D. He discovered the Red Junglefowl as the primary ancestor of modern chickens Correct Option: C
Question 8: Why were chickens ideal subjects for studying genetic inheritance? Options: A. They have low genetic diversity and few distinct traits, B. They have a long generation time, making it easier to study genetic changes, C. They have high genetic diversity, many distinct traits, and a short generation time, D. They are easy to breed and have a large footprint Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is a major concern with the current industrial model of chicken production? Options: A. The high cost of production, B. The environmental impact and animal welfare concerns, C. The lack of genetic diversity in chicken breeds, D. The inability to meet global demand for chicken products Correct Option: B
Question 10: What can be inferred about human history and society from the study of chicken domestication and development? Options: A. Humans have always prioritized animal welfare and environmental concerns, B. Humans have a long history of exploiting animals for food, entertainment, and other purposes, C. Humans have only recently begun to domesticate animals, D. Humans have made little progress in understanding genetic inheritance and breeding Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 7. 

This question has a similar intent to the ground truth MCQ, as it asks about Charles Darwin's contribution to the study of chickens and his theory of Evolution. The correct option (C) in Question 7 mentions that Darwin observed chickens and wondered if a similar selective breeding process occurred in nature, influencing his theory of Evolution. This is similar to the correct option (D) in the ground truth MCQ, which states that if humans could breed so many different types of chicken, then so could nature.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 20, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
The annals of Ancient Egyptian king 
Thutmose III described a marvelous foreign bird that “gives birth daily.” Zoroastrians viewed them as spirits whose cries told of the cosmic struggle between darkness and light. Romans brought them on
their military campaigns to foretell the success of future battles. And today, this bird still occupies
an important, though much less honorable position – on our dinner plates. The modern chicken is descended
primarily from the Red Junglefowl, and partially from three other 
closely related species, all native to India and Southeast Asia. The region’s bamboo plants produce massive amounts of fruit just once every few decades. Junglefowls’ ability to lay eggs daily may have evolved to take advantage 
of these rare feasts, increasing their population
when food was abundant. This was something humans could exploit on a consistent basis, and the birds’ weak flight capabilities and limited need for space made them easy to capture and contain. The earliest domesticated chickens, dating at least back to 7,000 years ago, weren’t bred for food, but for something considered
less savory today. The aggressiveness of breeding males, armed with natural leg spurs, made cockfighting a popular entertainment. By the second millennium BCE, chickens had spread from the 
Indus Valley to China and the Middle East to occupy
royal menageries and to be used in religious rituals. But it was in Egypt where the next chapter in
the bird’s history began. When a hen naturally incubates eggs, she will stop laying new ones and sit on a “clutch” of 6
or more eggs for 21 days. By the middle of the 1st millennium BCE, the Egyptians had learned to artificially incubate chicken eggs by placing them in baskets over hot ashes. That freed up hens to continue
laying daily, and what had been a royal delicacy or religious offering became a common meal. Around the same time as Egyptians
were incubating eggs, Phoenician merchants introduced
chickens to Europe, where they quickly became
an essential part of European livestock. However, for a long time, the chicken’s revered status 
continued to exist alongside its culinary one. The Ancient Greeks used fighting roosters as inspirational examples 
for young soldiers. The Romans consulted chickens as oracles. And as late as the 7th Century, the chicken was considered
a symbol for Christianity. Over the next few centuries, chickens accompanied humans
wherever they went, spreading throughout the world
through trade, conquest, and colonization. After the Opium Wars, Chinese breeds were brought to England and crossed with local chickens. This gave rise to a phenomenon called “Hen Fever” or “The Fancy”, with farmers all over Europe striving to breed new varieties with particular combinations of traits. This trend also caught the attention of a certain Charles Darwin,
who wondered if a similar selective breeding process
occurred in nature. Darwin would observe hundreds of chickens while finalizing his historic work introducing the theory of Evolution. But the chicken’s greatest
contribution to science was yet to come. In the early 20th century, a trio of British scientists conducted extensive crossbreeding
of chickens, building on Gregor Mendel’s studies of genetic inheritance. With their high genetic diversity, many distinct traits, and only 7 months between generations, chickens were the perfect subject. This work resulted in the famous
Punnett Square, used to show the genotypes
that would result from breeding a given pairing. Since then, numerous breeding initiatives
have made chickens bigger and meatier, and allowed them to lay 
more eggs than ever. Meanwhile, chicken production has shifted 
to an industrial, factory-like model, with birds raised in spaces 
with a footprint no larger than a sheet of paper. And while there’s been a shift
towards free-range farming due to animal rights 
and environmental concerns, most of the world’s more than
22 billion chickens today are factory farmed. From gladiators and gifts to the gods, to traveling companions 
and research subjects, chickens have played many roles
over the centuries. And though they may not have come 
before the proverbial egg, chickens’ fascinating history tells us 
a great deal about our own.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Why are chickens a good species to help us study genetics?
Options: A. Chickens take only 7 months between generations, B. Chickens have a wide variety of traits, C. Chickens have high genetic diversity, D. All of the above.
Correct Option: D

Question: Why do modern chickens make more meat and eggs than earlier chickens or junglefowl?

Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 21, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Mounting his skinny steed, the protagonist of Don Quixote charges an army of giants. In his eyes, it is his duty to vanquish these behemoths in the name of his beloved lady, Dulcinea. However, this act of valor is ill conceived. As his squire Sancho Panza explains to him time and again, these aren’t giants; they are merely windmills. Don Quixote is undeterred, but his piercing lance is soon caught in their sails. Never discouraged, the knight stands proudly, and becomes even more convinced of his mission. This sequence encapsulates much of what is loved about Don Quixote, the epic, illogical, and soulful tale of Alonso Quijano, who becomes the clumsy but valiant Don Quixote of la Mancha, known as the Knight of the Sorrowful Countenance. Originally published in two volumes, the narrative follows Don Quixote as he travels through central and northern Spain fighting the forces of evil. Despite Don Quixote’s lofty imagination, his creator, Miguel de Cervantes, could never have imagined his book would become the best-selling novel of all time. Barring 5 years as a soldier, and 5 more enslaved by pirates, Cervantes spent most of his life as a struggling poet and playwright. It wasn’t until his late 50’s that he published his greatest creation: an epic satire of chivalry novels. At this time, medieval books chronicling the adventures of knights and their moral code dominated European culture. While Cervantes was a fan, he was weary of these repetitive tomes, which focused more on listing heroic feats than character development. To challenge them, he wrote Don Quixote, the story of a hidalgo, or idle nobleman, who spends his days and nights reading chivalry novels. Driven mad by these stories, he fashions himself a champion for the downtrodden. Everyone in his village tries to convince him to give up his lunacy, going so far as to burn some of the lurid books in his personal library. But Don Quixote is unstoppable. He dresses up in old shining armor, mounts his skinny horse, and leaves his village in search of glory. Cervantes’ novel unfolds as a collection of episodes detailing the mishaps of the valiant knight. Yet unlike the chivalry books and perhaps all other prior fiction, Cervantes’ story deeply investigates the protagonist’s inner life. Don Quixote matures as the narrative develops, undergoing a noticeable transformation. This literary revelation has led many scholars to call Don Quixote the first modern novel. And this character development doesn’t happen in isolation. Early on, Don Quixote is joined by a villager-turned-squire named Sancho Panza. Sancho and Don Quixote are a study in opposites: with one as the grounded realist to the other’s idealism. Their lively, evolving friendship is often credited as the original hero and sidekick duo, inspiring centuries of fictional partnerships. Don Quixote was a huge success. Numerous editions were published across Europe in the seventeenth century. Even in the Americas, where the Church banned all novels for being sinful distractions, audiences were known to enjoy pirated editions. The book was so well received that readers clamored for more. After a rival author attempted to cash in on a fake follow-up, Cervantes released the official sequel in response. Now published alongside the first volume as a completed text, this second volume picks up where the original left off, only now Don Quixote and Sancho have become folk heroes. Just as in real-life, Cervantes included his novel’s success in the world of his characters. This unconventional meta-awareness created philosophical complexity, as the knight and his squire ponder the meaning of their story. Unfortunately, Cervantes had sold the book’s publishing rights for very little. He died rich in fame alone. But his treatise on the power of creativity and individualism has inspired art, literature, popular culture, and even political revolution. Don Quixote argues that our imagination greatly informs our actions, making us capable of change, and, indeed, making us human.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Why do Don Quixote and Sancho Panza work well together?
Options: A. They eat at strange times of the day, B. They are impatient, C. They like to dance together, D. Their characters complement each other
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who is the protagonist of the novel "Don Quixote"? Options: A. Alonso Quijano, B. Miguel de Cervantes, C. Sancho Panza, D. Dulcinea Correct Option: A
Question 2: What is the central theme of the novel "Don Quixote" that has inspired art, literature, and popular culture? Options: A. The power of wealth and status, B. The importance of chivalry and honor, C. The impact of imagination on our actions and humanity, D. The struggle between good and evil Correct Option: C
Question 3: If you were to adapt "Don Quixote" into a modern-day film, how would you portray the character of Don Quixote to make him relatable to contemporary audiences? Options: A. As a superhero with extraordinary powers, B. As a romantic lead with a charming personality, C. As a complex, flawed individual driven by his imagination and ideals, D. As a comedic figure with exaggerated mannerisms Correct Option: C
Question 4: Analyze the relationship between Don Quixote and Sancho Panza. What does their friendship represent in the context of the novel? Options: A. The struggle between good and evil, B. The contrast between reality and imagination, C. The bond between two like-minded individuals, D. The dichotomy between idealism and realism Correct Option: D
Question 5: What literary innovation is attributed to "Don Quixote" that sets it apart from earlier works of fiction? Options: A. The use of first-person narration, B. The inclusion of fantastical elements, C. The exploration of the protagonist's inner life and character development, D. The use of poetic language Correct Option: C
Question 6: How does the novel "Don Quixote" critique the chivalry novels of its time? Options: A. By ridiculing their romantic ideals, B. By emulating their heroic feats, C. By challenging their lack of character development and repetitive storylines, D. By ignoring their influence on literature Correct Option: C
Question 7: What was the impact of "Don Quixote" on the literary world during the 17th century? Options: A. It was widely criticized for its satirical tone, B. It was largely ignored by readers and scholars, C. It became a huge success, with numerous editions published across Europe, D. It was banned by the Church for its perceived sinful content Correct Option: C
Question 8: Evaluate the significance of the meta-awareness in the second volume of "Don Quixote", where the characters ponder the meaning of their story. What does this literary device achieve? Options: A. It creates a sense of realism and authenticity, B. It adds complexity to the narrative and explores the nature of storytelling, C. It detracts from the main plot and confuses the reader, D. It undermines the authority of the author Correct Option: B
Question 9: How does the character of Don Quixote change throughout the novel? Options: A. He becomes increasingly idealistic and detached from reality, B. He remains static, with no significant development or growth, C. He matures and undergoes a noticeable transformation, D. He becomes more cynical and disillusioned with the world Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the ultimate message of "Don Quixote" regarding the human condition? Options: A. That we are limited by our circumstances and cannot change, B. That our imagination has the power to shape our actions and make us human, C. That reality is more important than idealism, D. That we should strive for perfection and heroism Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 4. 

This question analyzes the relationship between Don Quixote and Sancho Panza, which aligns with the intent of the ground truth MCQ. The correct option (D) in Question 4, "The dichotomy between idealism and realism," highlights the complementary nature of their characters, similar to the correct option (D) in the ground truth MCQ, "Their characters complement each other." 

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 4.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 21, Question 2

To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Mounting his skinny steed, the protagonist of Don Quixote charges an army of giants. In his eyes, it is his duty to vanquish these behemoths in the name of his beloved lady, Dulcinea. However, this act of valor is ill conceived. As his squire Sancho Panza explains to him time and again, these aren’t giants; they are merely windmills. Don Quixote is undeterred, but his piercing lance is soon caught in their sails. Never discouraged, the knight stands proudly, and becomes even more convinced of his mission. This sequence encapsulates much of what is loved about Don Quixote, the epic, illogical, and soulful tale of Alonso Quijano, who becomes the clumsy but valiant Don Quixote of la Mancha, known as the Knight of the Sorrowful Countenance. Originally published in two volumes, the narrative follows Don Quixote as he travels through central and northern Spain fighting the forces of evil. Despite Don Quixote’s lofty imagination, his creator, Miguel de Cervantes, could never have imagined his book would become the best-selling novel of all time. Barring 5 years as a soldier, and 5 more enslaved by pirates, Cervantes spent most of his life as a struggling poet and playwright. It wasn’t until his late 50’s that he published his greatest creation: an epic satire of chivalry novels. At this time, medieval books chronicling the adventures of knights and their moral code dominated European culture. While Cervantes was a fan, he was weary of these repetitive tomes, which focused more on listing heroic feats than character development. To challenge them, he wrote Don Quixote, the story of a hidalgo, or idle nobleman, who spends his days and nights reading chivalry novels. Driven mad by these stories, he fashions himself a champion for the downtrodden. Everyone in his village tries to convince him to give up his lunacy, going so far as to burn some of the lurid books in his personal library. But Don Quixote is unstoppable. He dresses up in old shining armor, mounts his skinny horse, and leaves his village in search of glory. Cervantes’ novel unfolds as a collection of episodes detailing the mishaps of the valiant knight. Yet unlike the chivalry books and perhaps all other prior fiction, Cervantes’ story deeply investigates the protagonist’s inner life. Don Quixote matures as the narrative develops, undergoing a noticeable transformation. This literary revelation has led many scholars to call Don Quixote the first modern novel. And this character development doesn’t happen in isolation. Early on, Don Quixote is joined by a villager-turned-squire named Sancho Panza. Sancho and Don Quixote are a study in opposites: with one as the grounded realist to the other’s idealism. Their lively, evolving friendship is often credited as the original hero and sidekick duo, inspiring centuries of fictional partnerships. Don Quixote was a huge success. Numerous editions were published across Europe in the seventeenth century. Even in the Americas, where the Church banned all novels for being sinful distractions, audiences were known to enjoy pirated editions. The book was so well received that readers clamored for more. After a rival author attempted to cash in on a fake follow-up, Cervantes released the official sequel in response. Now published alongside the first volume as a completed text, this second volume picks up where the original left off, only now Don Quixote and Sancho have become folk heroes. Just as in real-life, Cervantes included his novel’s success in the world of his characters. This unconventional meta-awareness created philosophical complexity, as the knight and his squire ponder the meaning of their story. Unfortunately, Cervantes had sold the book’s publishing rights for very little. He died rich in fame alone. But his treatise on the power of creativity and individualism has inspired art, literature, popular culture, and even political revolution. Don Quixote argues that our imagination greatly informs our actions, making us capable of change, and, indeed, making us human.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Why does Don Quixote want to fix the world?
Options: A. He is a knight who believes in social justice, B. He reads many books, C. He doesn’t have any friends, D. He loves toys
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who is the protagonist of the novel "Don Quixote"? Options: A. Alonso Quijano, B. Miguel de Cervantes, C. Sancho Panza, D. Dulcinea Correct Option: A
Question 2: What is the central theme of the novel "Don Quixote" that has inspired art, literature, and popular culture? Options: A. The power of wealth and status, B. The importance of chivalry and honor, C. The impact of imagination on our actions and humanity, D. The struggle between good and evil Correct Option: C
Question 3: If you were to adapt "Don Quixote" into a modern-day film, how would you portray the character of Don Quixote to make him relatable to contemporary audiences? Options: A. As a superhero with extraordinary powers, B. As a romantic lead with a charming personality, C. As a complex, flawed individual driven by his imagination and ideals, D. As a comedic figure with exaggerated mannerisms Correct Option: C
Question 4: Analyze the relationship between Don Quixote and Sancho Panza. What does their friendship represent in the context of the novel? Options: A. The struggle between good and evil, B. The contrast between reality and imagination, C. The bond between two like-minded individuals, D. The dichotomy between idealism and realism Correct Option: D
Question 5: What literary innovation is attributed to "Don Quixote" that sets it apart from earlier works of fiction? Options: A. The use of first-person narration, B. The inclusion of fantastical elements, C. The exploration of the protagonist's inner life and character development, D. The use of poetic language Correct Option: C
Question 6: How does the novel "Don Quixote" critique the chivalry novels of its time? Options: A. By ridiculing their romantic ideals, B. By emulating their heroic feats, C. By challenging their lack of character development and repetitive storylines, D. By ignoring their influence on literature Correct Option: C
Question 7: What was the impact of "Don Quixote" on the literary world during the 17th century? Options: A. It was widely criticized for its satirical tone, B. It was largely ignored by readers and scholars, C. It became a huge success, with numerous editions published across Europe, D. It was banned by the Church for its perceived sinful content Correct Option: C
Question 8: Evaluate the significance of the meta-awareness in the second volume of "Don Quixote", where the characters ponder the meaning of their story. What does this literary device achieve? Options: A. It creates a sense of realism and authenticity, B. It adds complexity to the narrative and explores the nature of storytelling, C. It detracts from the main plot and confuses the reader, D. It undermines the authority of the author Correct Option: B
Question 9: How does the character of Don Quixote change throughout the novel? Options: A. He becomes increasingly idealistic and detached from reality, B. He remains static, with no significant development or growth, C. He matures and undergoes a noticeable transformation, D. He becomes more cynical and disillusioned with the world Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the ultimate message of "Don Quixote" regarding the human condition? Options: A. That we are limited by our circumstances and cannot change, B. That our imagination has the power to shape our actions and make us human, C. That reality is more important than idealism, D. That we should strive for perfection and heroism Correct Option: B

Mounting his skinny steed, the protagonist of Don Quixote charges an army of giants. In his eyes, it is his duty to vanquish these behemoths in the name of his beloved lady, Dulcinea. However, this act of valor is ill conceived. As his squire Sancho Panza explains to him time and again, these aren’t giants; they are merely windmills. Don Quixote is undeterred, but his piercing lance is soon caught in their sails. Never discouraged, the knight stands proudly, and becomes even more convinced of his mission. This sequence encapsulates much of what is loved about Don Quixote, the epic, illogical, and soulful tale of Alonso Quijano, who becomes the clumsy but valiant Don Quixote of la Mancha, known as the Knight of the Sorrowful Countenance. Originally published in two volumes, the narrative follows Don Quixote as he travels through central and northern Spain fighting the forces of evil. Despite Don Quixote’s lofty imagination, his creator, Miguel de Cervantes, could never have imagined his book would become the best-selling novel of all time. To challenge them, he wrote Don Quixote, the story of a hidalgo, or idle nobleman, who spends his days and nights reading chivalry novels. This unconventional meta-awareness created philosophical complexity, as the knight and his squire ponder the meaning of their story. Unfortunately, Cervantes had sold the book’s publishing rights for very little. He died rich in fame alone. As a superhero with extraordinary powers, B. As a romantic lead with a charming personality, C. As a complex, flawed individual driven by his imagination and ideals, D. As a comedic figure with exaggerated mannerisms Correct Option: C
Question 4: Analyze the relationship between Don Quixote and Sancho Panza. What does their friendship represent in the context of the novel? Options: A. The struggle between good and evil, B. The contrast between reality and imagination, C. The bond between two like-minded individuals, D. The dichotomy between idealism and realism Correct Option: D
Question 5: What literary innovation is attributed to "Don Quixote" that sets it apart from earlier works of fiction? Options: A. The use of first-person narration, B. The inclusion of fantastical elements, C. The exploration of the protagonist's inner life and character development, D. The use of poetic language Correct Option: C
Question 6: How does the novel "Don Quixote" critique the chivalry novels of its time? Options: A. By ridiculing their romantic ideals, B. By emulating their heroic feats, C. By challenging their lack of character development and repetitive storylines, D. By ignoring their influence on literature Correct Option: C
Question 7: What was the impact of "Don Quixote" on the literary world during the 17th century? Options: A. It was widely criticized for its satirical tone, B. It was largely ignored by readers and scholars, C. It became a huge success, with numerous editions published across Europe, D. It was banned by the Church for its perceived sinful content Correct Option: C
Question 8: Evaluate the significance of the meta-awareness in the second volume of "Don Quixote", where the characters ponder the meaning of their story. What does this literary device achieve? Options: A. It creates a sense of realism and authenticity, B. It adds complexity to the narrative and explores the nature of storytelling, C. It detracts from the main plot and confuses the reader, D. It undermines the authority of the author Correct Option: B
Question 9: How does the character of Don Quixote change throughout the novel? Options: A. He becomes increasingly idealistic and detached from reality, B. He remains static, with no significant development or growth, C. He matures and undergoes a noticeable transformation, D. He becomes more cynical and disillusioned with the world Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the ultimate message of "Don Quixote" regarding the human condition? Options: A. That we are limited by our circumstances and cannot change, B. That our imagination has the power to shape our actions and make us human, C. That reality is more important than idealism, D. That we should strive for perfection and heroism Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The ground truth MCQ asks about the meaning of the term "quixotic." Although none of the generated MCQs directly ask about this term, we can infer that the term "quixotic" refers to someone who is idealistic, romantic, and prone to exaggeration, much like the character of Don Quixote.

Based on this understanding, the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 10: "What is the ultimate message of 'Don Quixote' regarding the human condition?" Options: A. That we are limited by our circumstances and cannot change, B. That our imagination has the power to shape our actions and make us human, C. That reality is more important than idealism, D. That we should strive for perfection and heroism.

The correct option, B, suggests that our imagination plays a significant role in shaping our actions and humanity, which aligns with the concept of being "quixotic." Therefore, the index of the most similar generated MCQ is 10.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 22, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Why does every keyboard look like this? OK, so this top strip here, there is a 99% chance that on your keyboard it's:  We all have these QWERTY keyboards. There’s probably even one in your pocket, on a screen. But why? Why is this pattern of letters so familiar? “This of course, is the keyboard.” But why, "of course?" QWERTY was just one person’s invention from the 1870s. It’s almost 140 years old,  yet, it's still the standard. “All of these machines are alike in many respects.” We all use it, but don’t know why.  That’s the definition of overrated! And it turns out that this little keyboard is the subject of intense debate, some lies you’ve probably been told before, and a few real explanations that might surprise you.  Including an old fashioned cartel. Lots of people have tried to arrange these jumbled letters. There was a half century period of indecision. Debate. In the 1840's, Hughes Printing Telegraph arranged 
the keys like a piano keyboard. Or, look at the Hansen’s Writing Ball from 1865. People’s fingers pecked at this thing. The letters varied per version, but they showed up in this pattern. This 1868 typewriter looks weird too, 
but it was the start of something. The inventor, was Christopher Latham Sholes. He looked like typewriter Santa Claus,
and he kept going. In 1870, he developed a pattern like this. As of 1873, he’d come up with a keyboard that 
looked a lot like QWERTY. But there were quirks. Notice that period where the R should be. And the A and Z are flipped. The M 
also sits next to the L. Remington, a company that made machines for shooting and sewing, bought the design. Suddenly, they were in the typewriter business. The design Sholes patented in 1878 was basically QWERTY. Along with the numbers, the only weirdness is that M next to the L, and the C and X are flipped compared to a
contemporary keyboard. The company that made Remington Typewriters was soon sending out 
sales packets with the QWERTY we know and love. But that doesn’t quite explain how QWERTY got big. There are urban legends. One’s that QWERTY was designed that way to keep typewriter keys from jamming. But lots of designs could do that, and there’s not a lot of good evidence that 
that's why QWERTY was designed. Other options were even still around in 1890, like the Merritt Typewriter. You moved this handle to the right spot
for your letter and pressed down. The letters weren’t in QWERTY, they were in a big long strip that looked like this. So it was  a KWBHGP keyboard. Many typists believed it worked as well as QWERTY. But the best evidence of all that
QWERTY wasn’t “the perfect design,” might be this invention from 1889. The keyboard? Not QWERTY, but XPMCHR. The inventor? Christopher Latham Sholes, the guy who invented QWERTY. He created it just before he died. Even the creator of QWERTY wasn’t settled on QWERTY! And that’s where the cartel comes in. Look at this king. He has something to do with QWERTY. See the label on his crown?  "Trusts." In the 1890s, many companies merged into trusts that allowed 
them to fix prices and control markets. In 1893, that happened with typewriters, when some of the biggest manufacturers came
together to form Union Typewriter Company. Manufacturers cared most about price and technical improvements, like how the typewriter worked. But there was another effect of the trust. The biggest company made Remington Typewriters, and they used Sholes’ QWERTY keyboard design. The trust did the same. Most experts think the trust didn’t work to fix prices. It had trouble beating innovative competitors. But their market power did fix a pattern on the keyboard. And there’s one more reason why that pattern stuck. Look at these old typewriter ads. Or these early typists. Now you might notice that most of these students are women. That is worth noting! But for the story of QWERTY, it’s more important 
to notice that they’re in a class, together. Typing wasn’t like it is today, where you get one of these at the office, or one of these when you’re born. Typists trained. They took classes. If you took a class, you took it for the most common keyboard. That was QWERTY. People still debate whether QWERTY’s the best. Some say the 1930s DVORAK keyboard is better, others say it too is overrated. Whether it’s the best system or not, QWERTY isn’t going anywhere anytime soon. “How you type is more important than what you type.” “This is the mark of a good typist.” There are so many other unprovable theories 
when it comes to QWERTY. One of my favorites is that the 
keyboard was arranged that way so that sales people could peck out TYPEWRITER 
all on the top of the keyboard.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Who was the inventor of the QWERTY keyboard?
Options: A. Samuel W. Soule, B. William Austin Burt, C. Christopher Latham Sholes
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who is credited with inventing the QWERTY keyboard? Options: A. Christopher Latham Sholes, B. Remington, C. Hughes Printing Telegraph, D. Hansen Correct Option: A
Question 2: What was the name of the company that bought Christopher Latham Sholes' typewriter design and began mass-producing QWERTY keyboards? Options: A. Remington, B. Union Typewriter Company, C. Hansen's Writing Ball, D. Hughes Printing Telegraph Correct Option: A
Question 3: What is one common myth about the QWERTY keyboard layout, and what is the truth behind it? Options: A. The QWERTY layout was designed to slow down typing, but it was actually designed to prevent key jamming., B. The QWERTY layout was designed to prevent key jamming, but there's no evidence to support this claim., C. The QWERTY layout was designed for efficiency, and it has been proven to be the most efficient layout., D. The QWERTY layout was designed for aesthetics, and its design has been widely praised. Correct Option: B
Question 4: What was the result of the formation of the Union Typewriter Company in 1893, and how did it impact the keyboard layout? Options: A. The company standardized the QWERTY layout, which became the industry standard., B. The company created a new keyboard layout that was more efficient than QWERTY., C. The company allowed manufacturers to create their own keyboard layouts, leading to a proliferation of different designs., D. The company had no impact on the keyboard layout. Correct Option: A
Question 5: Why did typists in the early days of typing tend to learn the QWERTY layout, and what was the result of this trend? Options: A. Typists learned QWERTY because it was the most efficient layout, and as a result, it became the industry standard., B. Typists learned QWERTY because it was the most common layout, and as a result, it became the de facto standard., C. Typists learned QWERTY because it was required by law, and as a result, it became the only layout used., D. Typists learned QWERTY because it was the cheapest layout to produce, and as a result, it became the most widely used. Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the name of the keyboard layout that some experts claim is more efficient than QWERTY, and what is the basis for this claim? Options: A. The DVORAK layout, which is claimed to be more efficient because it places the most common letters in the home row., B. The QWERTZ layout, which is claimed to be more efficient because it places the most common letters in the top row., C. The AZERTY layout, which is claimed to be more efficient because it places the most common letters in the bottom row., D. The Colemak layout, which is claimed to be more efficient because it places the most common letters in a diagonal pattern. Correct Option: A
Question 7: If you were a manufacturer of typewriters in the late 19th century, what would be the most important factor in determining the keyboard layout you would use? Options: A. The efficiency of the layout, B. The aesthetics of the layout, C. The cost of producing the layout, D. The compatibility of the layout with existing machines Correct Option: D
Question 8: What was the impact of the trust formed by typewriter manufacturers in 1893 on the keyboard layout, and what were the consequences of this impact? Options: A. The trust led to the standardization of the QWERTY layout, which became the industry standard and has remained so to this day., B. The trust led to the creation of a new keyboard layout that was more efficient than QWERTY, but it was not widely adopted., C. The trust led to a proliferation of different keyboard layouts, as manufacturers were free to create their own designs., D. The trust had no impact on the keyboard layout. Correct Option: A
Question 9: If you were a typist in the early 20th century, what would be the most important factor in determining your typing speed and accuracy? Options: A. The type of typewriter you used, B. The keyboard layout you used, C. The amount of practice you had, D. The method of typing you used (e.g. touch typing vs. hunt-and-peck) Correct Option: D
Question 10: What is the main reason why the QWERTY keyboard layout has remained the standard despite the existence of more efficient layouts? Options: A. The QWERTY layout is the most efficient layout for typing., B. The QWERTY layout is the most aesthetically pleasing layout., C. The QWERTY layout is the most widely used layout, and therefore it has become the de facto standard., D. The QWERTY layout is required by law or industry regulations. Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is:

**Question 1: Who is credited with inventing the QWERTY keyboard? Options: A. Christopher Latham Sholes, B. Remington, C. Hughes Printing Telegraph, D. Hansen Correct Option: A**

This question has the same intent as the ground truth MCQ, which is to identify the inventor of the QWERTY keyboard. The correct option, Christopher Latham Sholes, is also the same in both questions. The options in the generated MCQ are slightly different, but they are all plausible alternatives, making it a good match.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 23, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
The good news is that your experimental robo-ants are a success! The bad news is that you accidentally just gave them the ability to shoot deadly lasers …and you can’t turn it off. You have five minutes to stop them before the lasers go online. Until then, all of your robo-ants will walk inside their habitat at a speed of exactly 1 meter per minute. If they bump into each other or hit a dead end, they’ll instantly turn around and walk back the way they came. When five minutes are up, they’ll turn on their lasers, break free, and stream out into the world, carving a path of destruction as they go. Your one chance to stop them is to insert the two emergency vacuum nozzles into the habitat and suck the ants up before they break free. The nozzles can press into any one location in the habitat through a membrane covering its front side, and any ants that walk past will be sucked up and deactivated. You can’t move the nozzles once they’re placed without leaving a hole that the robo-ants would pour out of, so choosing the right spots will be key. The habitat is made out of meter-long tubes. When the robots reach an intersection, they will pick randomly whether to go left, right, or forward. They only go backward if they hit hit another robo-ant or a dead end. Unfortunately, there are hundreds of them inside the habitat, and if even one escapes, it’ll do a lot of damage. With just less than five minutes remaining, where should you place the 2 vacuum nozzles to suck up all the robo-ants? Pause the video now if
you want to figure it out for yourself. Answer in: 3 Answer in: 2 Answer in: 1 With robo-ants ricocheting all over the habitat, it might seem impossible to stop them before they break free. But this situation is simpler than it seems. Here's why. Imagine just two robo-ants crawling toward each other. When they collide, they immediately reverse directions. And what would that sequence of events look like if they crawled past each other instead? It would look exactly the same before and after their collision, but with their positions swapped. This is true every time a pair of robo-ants meet. Because the identities of individual ants don’t matter, you just need to figure out where you should put the nozzles to capture any single ant walking without interruption for less than 5 minutes, starting from any point in the habitat. That’s much easier to conceptualize and solve. Placing the nozzles at intersections where three or four tubes meet seems like your best bet since that’s where the robo-ants might otherwise change directions and miss your nozzles. There are only four intersections… which two should you pick? The top right intersection has to be one of them. If it isn’t, an ant crawling down from this intersection toward the dead end would crawl for four minutes to get back to the intersection, and then go in any of three directions, walking for at least another minute. Once you’ve placed a nozzle in the top right, the only other choice that has a chance to work is the bottom left. To see that this works, imagine an ant anywhere else in the habitat. Worst case scenario, the ant would start right next to the vacuum nozzle, marching away from it. But in all those worst cases, the ant would march for at most 4 meters before being sucked up into the vacuum. No other choice of two intersection points is guaranteed to get all the robo-ants within five minutes. Having vacuumed them all up, you’ve averted a major crisis. Before you mess with robo-ants again, you’ll want to have a robo-anteater ready. And wouldn’t it be cool if it could fly and breathe fire? There’s no way that could go wrong!

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How fast do the robo-ants crawl?
Options: A. 1 meter per second, B. 1 meter per minute, C. 1 meter per hour, D. 50 meters per hour
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: At what speed do the robo-ants walk inside their habitat? Options: A. 0.5 meters per minute, B. 1 meter per minute, C. 2 meters per minute, D. 5 meters per minute Correct Option: B
Question 2: What happens when the robo-ants bump into each other or hit a dead end? Options: A. They stop moving, B. They change direction randomly, C. They instantly turn around and walk back the way they came, D. They break free from the habitat Correct Option: C
Question 3: What is the purpose of inserting the emergency vacuum nozzles into the habitat? Options: A. To provide oxygen to the robo-ants, B. To feed the robo-ants, C. To suck up and deactivate the robo-ants, D. To repair the habitat Correct Option: C
Question 4: If two robo-ants collide and then crawl past each other, what would the sequence of events look like? Options: A. The same as if they didn't collide, B. Different from if they didn't collide, C. The same before and after the collision, but with their positions swapped, D. Unpredictable Correct Option: C
Question 5: Why is it easier to conceptualize and solve the problem by considering a single ant walking without interruption? Options: A. Because the identities of individual ants don't matter, B. Because the robo-ants are moving randomly, C. Because the habitat is made of meter-long tubes, D. Because there are hundreds of robo-ants Correct Option: A
Question 6: Where should you place the vacuum nozzles to capture any single ant walking without interruption for less than 5 minutes? Options: A. At the dead ends of the tubes, B. At the intersections where three or four tubes meet, C. In the middle of the tubes, D. At the entrance of the habitat Correct Option: B
Question 7: Which intersection point must be chosen as one of the nozzle locations? Options: A. Top left, B. Top right, C. Bottom left, D. Bottom right Correct Option: B
Question 8: What would happen if an ant starts right next to the vacuum nozzle at the bottom left intersection? Options: A. It would be sucked up immediately, B. It would march for at most 4 meters before being sucked up, C. It would march for at least 5 meters before being sucked up, D. It would escape the habitat Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the worst-case scenario for an ant starting anywhere else in the habitat? Options: A. It would start right next to the vacuum nozzle, B. It would start at the dead end of a tube, C. It would start at an intersection with three tubes, D. It would start at an intersection with four tubes Correct Option: A
Question 10: What can be concluded about the solution to the problem? Options: A. There are multiple possible solutions, B. The solution is unique and guaranteed to work, C. The solution is probabilistic and may not work, D. There is no solution to the problem Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent (asking about the speed of the robo-ants), options (providing different speeds), and content (focusing on the speed of the robo-ants). The correct option in both questions is also the same, which is 1 meter per minute.

To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
The good news is that your experimental robo-ants are a success! The bad news is that you accidentally just gave them the ability to shoot deadly lasers …and you can’t turn it off. You have five minutes to stop them before the lasers go online. Until then, all of your robo-ants will walk inside their habitat at a speed of exactly 1 meter per minute. If they bump into each other or hit a dead end, they’ll instantly turn around and walk back the way they came. When five minutes are up, they’ll turn on their lasers, break free, and stream out into the world, carving a path of destruction as they go. Your one chance to stop them is to insert the two emergency vacuum nozzles into the habitat and suck the ants up before they break free. The nozzles can press into any one location in the habitat through a membrane covering its front side, and any ants that walk past will be sucked up and deactivated. You can’t move the nozzles once they’re placed without leaving a hole that the robo-ants would pour out of, so choosing the right spots will be key. The habitat is made out of meter-long tubes. When the robots reach an intersection, they will pick randomly whether to go left, right, or forward. They only go backward if they hit hit another robo-ant or a dead end. Unfortunately, there are hundreds of them inside the habitat, and if even one escapes, it’ll do a lot of damage. With just less than five minutes remaining, where should you place the 2 vacuum nozzles to suck up all the robo-ants? Pause the video now if
you want to figure it out for yourself. Answer in: 3 Answer in: 2 Answer in: 1 With robo-ants ricocheting all over the habitat, it might seem impossible to stop them before they break free. But this situation is simpler than it seems. Here's why. Imagine just two robo-ants crawling toward each other. When they collide, they immediately reverse directions. And what would that sequence of events look like if they crawled past each other instead? It would look exactly the same before and after their collision, but with their positions swapped. This is true every time a pair of robo-ants meet. Because the identities of individual ants don’t matter, you just need to figure out where you should put the nozzles to capture any single ant walking without interruption for less than 5 minutes, starting from any point in the habitat. That’s much easier to conceptualize and solve. Placing the nozzles at intersections where three or four tubes meet seems like your best bet since that’s where the robo-ants might otherwise change directions and miss your nozzles. There are only four intersections… which two should you pick? The top right intersection has to be one of them. If it isn’t, an ant crawling down from this intersection toward the dead end would crawl for four minutes to get back to the intersection, and then go in any of three directions, walking for at least another minute. Once you’ve placed a nozzle in the top right, the only other choice that has a chance to work is the bottom left. To see that this works, imagine an ant anywhere else in the habitat. Worst case scenario, the ant would start right next to the vacuum nozzle, marching away from it. But in all those worst cases, the ant would march for at most 4 meters before being sucked up into the vacuum. No other choice of two intersection points is guaranteed to get all the robo-ants within five minutes. Having vacuumed them all up, you’ve averted a major crisis. Before you mess with robo-ants again, you’ll want to have a robo-anteater ready. And wouldn’t it be cool if it could fly and breathe fire? There’s no way that could go wrong!

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How many vacuum nozzles do you have?
Options: A. 1, B. 2, C. 3, D. 4
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: At what speed do the robo-ants walk inside their habitat? Options: A. 0.5 meters per minute, B. 1 meter per minute, C. 2 meters per minute, D. 5 meters per minute Correct Option: B
Question 2: What happens when the robo-ants bump into each other or hit a dead end? Options: A. They stop moving, B. They change direction randomly, C. They instantly turn around and walk back the way they came, D. They break free from the habitat Correct Option: C
Question 3: What is the purpose of inserting the emergency vacuum nozzles into the habitat? Options: A. To provide oxygen to the robo-ants, B. To feed the robo-ants, C. To suck up and deactivate the robo-ants, D. To repair the habitat Correct Option: C
Question 4: If two robo-ants collide and then crawl past each other, what would the sequence of events look like? Options: A. The same as if they didn't collide, B. Different from if they didn't collide, C. The same before and after the collision, but with their positions swapped, D. Unpredictable Correct Option: C

Because the robo-ants are moving randomly, C. Because the habitat is made of meter-long tubes, D. Because there are hundreds of robo-ants Correct Option: A
Question 6: Where should you place the vacuum nozzles to capture any single ant walking without interruption for less than 5 minutes? Options: A. At the dead ends of the tubes, B. At the intersections where three or four tubes meet, C. In the middle of the tubes, D. At the entrance of the habitat Correct Option: B
Question 7: Which intersection point must be chosen as one of the nozzle locations? Options: A. Top left, B. Top right, C. Bottom left, D. Bottom right Correct Option: B
Question 8: What would happen if an ant starts right next to the vacuum nozzle at the bottom left intersection? Options: A. It would be sucked up immediately, B. It would march for at most 4 meters before being sucked up, C. It would march for at least 5 meters before being sucked up, D. It would escape the habitat Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the worst-case scenario for an ant starting anywhere else in the habitat? Options: A. It would start right next to the vacuum nozzle, B. It would start at the dead end of a tube, C. It would start at an intersection with three tubes, D. It would start at an intersection with four tubes Correct Option: A
Question 10: What can be concluded about the solution to the problem? Options: A. There are multiple possible solutions, B. The solution is unique and guaranteed to work, C. The solution is probabilistic and may not work, D. There is no solution to the problem Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 23, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
The good news is that your experimental robo-ants are a success! The bad news is that you accidentally just gave them the ability to shoot deadly lasers …and you can’t turn it off. You have five minutes to stop them before the lasers go online. Until then, all of your robo-ants will walk inside their habitat at a speed of exactly 1 meter per minute. If they bump into each other or hit a dead end, they’ll instantly turn around and walk back the way they came. When five minutes are up, they’ll turn on their lasers, break free, and stream out into the world, carving a path of destruction as they go. Your one chance to stop them is to insert the two emergency vacuum nozzles into the habitat and suck the ants up before they break free. The nozzles can press into any one location in the habitat through a membrane covering its front side, and any ants that walk past will be sucked up and deactivated. You can’t move the nozzles once they’re placed without leaving a hole that the robo-ants would pour out of, so choosing the right spots will be key. The habitat is made out of meter-long tubes. When the robots reach an intersection, they will pick randomly whether to go left, right, or forward. They only go backward if they hit hit another robo-ant or a dead end. Unfortunately, there are hundreds of them inside the habitat, and if even one escapes, it’ll do a lot of damage. With just less than five minutes remaining, where should you place the 2 vacuum nozzles to suck up all the robo-ants? Pause the video now if
you want to figure it out for yourself. Answer in: 3 Answer in: 2 Answer in: 1 With robo-ants ricocheting all over the habitat, it might seem impossible to stop them before they break free. But this situation is simpler than it seems. Here's why. Imagine just two robo-ants crawling toward each other. When they collide, they immediately reverse directions. And what would that sequence of events look like if they crawled past each other instead? It would look exactly the same before and after their collision, but with their positions swapped. This is true every time a pair of robo-ants meet. Because the identities of individual ants don’t matter, you just need to figure out where you should put the nozzles to capture any single ant walking without interruption for less than 5 minutes, starting from any point in the habitat. That’s much easier to conceptualize and solve. Placing the nozzles at intersections where three or four tubes meet seems like your best bet since that’s where the robo-ants might otherwise change directions and miss your nozzles. There are only four intersections… which two should you pick? The top right intersection has to be one of them. If it isn’t, an ant crawling down from this intersection toward the dead end would crawl for four minutes to get back to the intersection, and then go in any of three directions, walking for at least another minute. Once you’ve placed a nozzle in the top right, the only other choice that has a chance to work is the bottom left. To see that this works, imagine an ant anywhere else in the habitat. Worst case scenario, the ant would start right next to the vacuum nozzle, marching away from it. But in all those worst cases, the ant would march for at most 4 meters before being sucked up into the vacuum. No other choice of two intersection points is guaranteed to get all the robo-ants within five minutes. Having vacuumed them all up, you’ve averted a major crisis. Before you mess with robo-ants again, you’ll want to have a robo-anteater ready. And wouldn’t it be cool if it could fly and breathe fire? There’s no way that could go wrong!

Options: A. Speed up, B. Pass each other without touching, C. Slow down, D. Reverse directions without changing speed
Correct Option: D

**Transcript**:
The good news is that your experimental robo-ants are a success! The bad news is that you accidentally just gave them the ability to shoot deadly lasers …and you can’t turn it off. You have five minutes to stop them before the lasers go online. Until then, all of your robo-ants will walk inside their habitat at a speed of exactly 1 meter per minute. If they bump into each other or hit a dead end, they’ll instantly turn around and walk back the way they came. When five minutes are up, they’ll turn on their lasers, break free, and stream out into the world, carving a path of destruction as they go. Your one chance to stop them is to insert the two emergency vacuum nozzles into the habitat and suck the ants up before they break free. The nozzles can press into any one location in the habitat through a membrane covering its front side, and any ants that walk past will be sucked up and deactivated. You can’t move the nozzles once they’re placed without leaving a hole that the robo-ants would pour out of, so choosing the right spots will be key. The habitat is made out of meter-long tubes. When the robots reach an intersection, they will pick randomly whether to go left, right, or forward. They only go backward if they hit hit another robo-ant or a dead end. Unfortunately, there are hundreds of them inside the habitat, and if even one escapes, it’ll do a lot of damage. With just less than five minutes remaining, where should you place the 2 vacuum nozzles to suck up all the robo-ants? Pause the video now if
you want to figure it out for yourself. Answer in: 3 Answer in: 2 Answer in: 1 With robo-ants ricocheting all over the habitat, it might seem impossible to stop them before they break free. But this situation is simpler than it seems. Here's why. Imagine just two robo-ants crawling toward each other. When they collide, they immediately reverse directions. And what would that sequence of events look like if they crawled past each other instead? It would look exactly the same before and after their collision, but with their positions swapped. This is true every time a pair of robo-ants meet. Because the identities of individual ants don’t matter, you just need to figure out where you should put the nozzles to capture any single ant walking without interruption for less than 5 minutes, starting from any point in the habitat. That’s much easier to conceptualize and solve. Placing the nozzles at intersections where three or four tubes meet seems like your best bet since that’s where the robo-ants might otherwise change directions and miss your nozzles. There are only four intersections… which two should you pick? The top right intersection has to be one of them. If it isn’t, an ant crawling down from this intersection toward the dead end would crawl for four minutes to get back to the intersection, and then go in any of three directions, walking for at least another minute. Once you’ve placed a nozzle in the top right, the only other choice that has a chance to work is the bottom left. To see that this works, imagine an ant anywhere else in the habitat. Worst case scenario, the ant would start right next to the vacuum nozzle, marching away from it. But in all those worst cases, the ant would march for at most 4 meters before being sucked up into the vacuum. No other choice of two intersection points is guaranteed to get all the robo-ants within five minutes. Having vacuumed them all up, you’ve averted a major crisis. Question: What do the ants do when they arrive at an intersection?
Options: A. Randomly go a direction that’s not the direction they came from, B. Randomly go any direction, C. Reverse directions, D. Go straight through the intersection
Correct Option: A
